articles.headline: Herbalife Safety Issue Draws Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Herbalife is at the heart of a Wall Street brawl. Now the company’s response to its handling of a product safety issue in 2011 is drawing scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Herbalife is at the heart of a Wall Street brawl. Now the company’s response to its handling of a product safety issue in 2011 is drawing scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:15 p.m. |  After Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company, began producing its best-selling drink mix at a plant in California, anxious executives had to scramble in early 2011 as they faced a potentially serious product safety threat.
articles.byline: By William Alden and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Sony Wants Pizzeria Out of Building in Midtown
articles.snippet: The dispute over Pizza da Solo follows the sale of the Sony Building, whose new owners have plans for a hotel-condominium tower.
articles.abstract: The dispute over Pizza da Solo follows the sale of the Sony Building, whose new owners have plans for a hotel-condominium tower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something as basic as a New York slice has provided the recipe for a fierce fight over a lease in the Sony Building in Midtown, pitting a restaurateur against giant landlords.

articles.headline: Divining the Regulatory Goals of Fed Rivals
articles.snippet: For supporters of stronger regulation, it comes down to a choice between someone they don’t know, Janet Yellen, and someone they don’t trust, Lawrence H. Summers.
articles.abstract: For supporters of stronger regulation, it comes down to a choice between someone they don’t know, Janet Yellen, and someone they don’t trust, Lawrence H. Summers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawrence H. Summers, as Treasury secretary, presided over the group of senior Clinton administration officials who reached the fateful decision in the late 1990s that there was no need to regulate a new family of financial transactions known as over-the-counter derivatives. Janet Yellen attended some of those meetings, too, as chairwoman of President Clinton’s Council of Economic Advisers. But she did not speak.

articles.headline: Competition, Not Mergers, May Bolster the Airlines
articles.snippet: The legacy carrier airlines that remain in operation must learn to survive in a competitive market, and to make money without turning routes and networks into monopolies.
articles.abstract: The legacy carrier airlines that remain in operation must learn to survive in a competitive market, and to make money without turning routes and networks into monopolies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can the American airline industry turn a profit in a competitive market?

articles.headline: Oil Reforms by Mexico May Upend Markets
articles.snippet: The suggested policy changes could reinvigorate the country’s oil industry and ease American dependence on OPEC, experts say.
articles.abstract: The suggested policy changes could reinvigorate the country’s oil industry and ease American dependence on OPEC, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A sweeping reform suggested for Mexico’s energy laws has the potential not only to return the country to its early-1980s heyday of energetic oil drilling, when it was one of the world’s most promising producers, but also to reduce further the United States’ dependence on OPEC producers, according to oil experts.

articles.headline: Germany Fights Population Drop
articles.snippet: As German towns work to hide the emptiness, demographers say a similar fate awaits other European countries, with frightening implications for the economy.
articles.abstract: As German towns work to hide the emptiness, demographers say a similar fate awaits other European countries, with frightening implications for the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SONNEBERG, Germany — At first glance, this town in central Germany, with rows of large houses built when it was a thriving center of toy manufacturing, looks tidy and prosperous. But Heiko Voigt, the deputy mayor here, can point out dozens of vacant homes that he doubts will ever be sold.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: To Judge Sleep Aids, U.S. Looks at Drowsy Driving in the Morning
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration is considering the residual drowsiness that can persist the day after taking prescription sleep aids, and whether users can drive safely upon waking.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is considering the residual drowsiness that can persist the day after taking prescription sleep aids, and whether users can drive safely upon waking.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first test for a new sleep drug is — unsurprisingly — how safely it puts people to sleep. Now comes a second test: how safely it lets people wake up.

articles.headline: North Carolinians Fear the End of a Middle Way
articles.snippet: With Republicans controlling all branches of the state government for the first time in more than a century, the legislature pushed through a range of conservative change.
articles.abstract: With Republicans controlling all branches of the state government for the first time in more than a century, the legislature pushed through a range of conservative change.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDEN, N.C. — When Pat McCrory, a Republican former mayor of Charlotte, was elected governor last year, he pledged to “bring this state together,” and to focus on bread-and-butter issues amid an ailing economy.

articles.headline: Unease at Clinton Foundation Over Finances and Ambitions
articles.snippet: In the coming weeks the Clinton Foundation, long Bill Clinton’s domain, will become the nerve center of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s increasingly busy public life.
articles.abstract: In the coming weeks the Clinton Foundation, long Bill Clinton’s domain, will become the nerve center of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s increasingly busy public life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after the 10th anniversary of the foundation bearing his name, Bill Clinton met with a small group of aides and two lawyers from Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. Two weeks of interviews with Clinton Foundation executives and former employees had led the lawyers to some unsettling conclusions.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Hundreds Die as Egyptian Forces Attack Islamist Protesters
articles.snippet: The scale and brutality of the attack on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, was the clearest sign yet that the old Egyptian police state was re-emerging in full force.
articles.abstract: The scale and brutality of the attack on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, was the clearest sign yet that the old Egyptian police state was re-emerging in full force.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian security officers stormed two encampments packed with supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, on Wednesday in a scorched-earth assault that killed hundreds, set off a violent backlash across Egypt and underscored the new government’s determination to crush the Islamists who dominated two years of free elections.

articles.headline: Euro Zone’s Recession Ends, at Least for Now
articles.snippet: Germany and France, the region’s two largest economies, each helped pull the zone out of its long contraction, second-quarter data shows.
articles.abstract: Germany and France, the region’s two largest economies, each helped pull the zone out of its long contraction, second-quarter data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bolstered by stronger consumption and investment in Germany as well as growth in France, Europe broke out of recession in the second quarter, ending its longest postwar contraction, official data showed on Wednesday. But the weak upturn, high unemployment and other problems on the Continent left open the question of whether the nascent recovery can last.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Alison Smale

articles.headline: To His Collection of Steinways, Hedge Fund Titan Adds Their Maker
articles.snippet: John A. Paulson, whose company has never before bought another company outright, said he was always enamored with Steinway pianos.
articles.abstract: John A. Paulson, whose company has never before bought another company outright, said he was always enamored with Steinway pianos.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:16 p.m. | John A. Paulson, the hedge fund billionaire, already owns three Steinway & Sons pianos: the medium model M grand, the larger model O and the nearly seven-foot-long model B, together worth tens of thousands of dollars.

articles.headline: Charges Against 2 Traders Fault JPMorgan for Lack of Oversight
articles.snippet: At a news conference announcing the arrest of two former traders at JPMorgan Chase, the authorities also criticized the bank’s oversight of the London office where they worked.
articles.abstract: At a news conference announcing the arrest of two former traders at JPMorgan Chase, the authorities also criticized the bank’s oversight of the London office where they worked.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than three thousand miles from the Park Avenue headquarters of JPMorgan Chase, traders in an office building nestled near the Thames River disguised the extent of their losses as a huge bet spun out of control last year, federal authorities say.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
